Posts.Content: Hey you guys, I just wanted to check in on the ED front. I was given Stendra by my uro, and tried the first dose over the weekend. Compared to Viagra, Stendra seemed to work (much) better for me. Very good results, and not as much nasal congestion. I was given the 200 mg tabs. I would say that it did kick in faster then Viagra, which I think was part of the hype when they rolled the drug out onto the market.
Posts.Signature: 45 years old +1 family history PC PSA 2012 2.0 PSA 2015 3.5 PSA 2015 3.2 fPSA 2015 < 10% PHI 2015 45.0 Normal DRE 2015: 12 core Bx, two positive for PC: Left Base (38%) 3+3=6 and Right Medium (1%) 3+3=6 Gleason No perineal involvement. Prolaris Study: -1.5, low risk Da Vinci 9-18-15 Gleason upgraded to 4+3=7 Bilateral Dz, less then 5% prostate effected. Prostate 32.3 Grams Focal involvement at right apex margin, no extraprostatic involvement; lymph nodes and vesicles clear. PSA Oct. 2015: undetectable

Posts.Title: WooHoo for the < sign!

Posts.Content: Thanks you guys, I needed a pat on the back and a kick in the ass, in no particular order. I have a copy of the path report coming by snail mail. I will get more details. The reason he gave me for low risk of reoccurrence at the apex was lack of blood flow to area. At the time, it sounded like he was throwing me a bone -- but if your surgeon said the same Oshguy, then I feel better about it, thanks. Ps, Merc, I was in the other thread today, please take it easy a little longer buddy. Lol.
Posts.Title: I need a Glass-Half-Full session here:

Posts.Content: Just got the phone call about Da Vinci post-op path you guys, and I'm telling myself it could be worse -- but I'm also discouraged to be honest. I (we) all hope that there is an end point where you are done and you can relax, that sounds like a rookie move in hindsight, doesn't it, but I guess I was looking for something to hang my hat on and be able to say yeah, this last week was all worth it. I got upgraded on histopath from a 3+3 to a Gleason 7 (4+3). There was also a small area on the margin which wasn't clean, apparently at the apex. Everything else like lymph nodes and vessicals was normal. The guy is saying we are talking microns here and he is not worried. He said there is a 90% chance I won't need radiation. It's not a concept I feel great about, it's just not a negative margin, so there's that. Davis.

Posts.Content: Hey Guys, first PSA Post Op is undetectable. I'm about five weeks past surgery, my guy checks everybody at 4-5 weeks. Feeling ok, I know I'm a long way from being done, but it's nice to have that first zero under my belt. Continence is mostly there, I'm still having some leaking when I (running implies you are fast) jog, or if my bladder is super full. Some ED present, I can achieve about 90% erection at times, but I'm finding it tough to maintain. I asked for some help at my recheck, and I'm supposed to pick up Stendra? I've not heard of it before. My best to everyone.

We can sit around 40 years from now and tell stories about manual transmissions, or even cars that didn't drive themselves... Have a good weekend you guys, D.

Posts.Title: Path Report, and nagging question

Posts.Content: So you guys I just got the hard copy of my pathology: Some of it is straightforward. Adenocarcinoma, Gleason 4+3 Score 7. Tumor present at right and left apex, in 7 of 26 slides. Comprising <5% of prostate gland. Prostate 32.8g. Tumor focally present (<200nm) right posterior apex margin. All other margins free of tumor. No extraprostatic extension, seminal vesicles free of tumor, 11/11 lymph nodes negative. No lymph or vascular invasion. Perineural invasion present. Now here is the concept I was hoping you guys could clue me in on: In the fine print... Margin involved by invasive carcinoma, focal right apex (Gleason 4), without extraprostatic extension (inked margin within prostate tissue) So, I remember Walsh saying in his book that the apex was tough because there was no clear demarcation of where prostate ends and spincter begins. My impression of the above is that the tumor was still in the prostate but there was still some prostatic tissue on the other side of the margin? If that is the case how do you track PSA post op? Will I ever have a non detectable PSA if there is still prostatic tissue in there? I'm guessing this is the part of the game, but any thoughts?
Posts.Signature: 45 years old +1 family history PC PSA 2012 2.0 PSA 2015 3.5 PSA 2015 3.2 fPSA 2015 < 10% PHI 2015 45.0 Normal DRE 2015: 12 core Bx, two positive for PC: Left Base (38%) 3+3=6 and Right Medium (1%) 3+3=6 Gleason No perineal involvement. Prolaris Study: -1.5, low risk Da Vinci 9-18-15 Gleason upgraded to 4+3=7 Bilateral Dz, less then 5% prostate effected. Prostate 32.3 Grams Focal involvement at right apex margin, no extraprostatic involvement; lymph nodes and vesicles clear. PSA Oct. 2015: undetectable
Posts.Title: Path Report, and nagging question

Posts.Content: Chuck, thanks for the link I will check it out tonight. Akai, thanks for the reference range, that helps me put it into perspective. Ron, that is a good point man, I'm bilateral and I also had two additional cores that had those atypical cell that were suspicious for PCa. So I'm probably the typical diffuse change of the whole prostatic gland. I don't know, I'm thinking of this test as a prognostic indicator (ie good prognosis) but not a game changer (ie I still have PC).

Posts.Title: Gleason 9 - First PSA post-surgery

Posts.Title: Gleason 9 - First PSA post-surgery

Posts.Content: Ok you guys, give me some feedback if you have time on this one. I just got off the phone with my urologist. While I was deciding about surgery I had him run the Prolaris test on my biopsy tissue. I had essentially decided to do the robot and ditch AS while I was waiting to hear from him. The score was -1.5 (no idea what the reference range was), but that puts me in a "very low risk" grouping apparently. I was getting the vibe from the uro that he is leaning toward AS now, but I may be reading too much into his inflection and I know it's a choice I that I have make. Any experience with the test? Fairly new, but is a DNA assay to determine aggressiveness of cell division.

Posts.Title: PSA Testing Probelms

Posts.Content: Ok, my apologies if this is covered somewhere else. I write this tongue in cheek, but man, could this deal get any worse? lol. I was having my surgical consult the other day and my guy is going through all the potential complications of the robotic procedure. I'm sitting there and he is talking strictures, yea ok: incontinence for awhile, yea fine, heard about it: ED, right ok, save the nerves dude: shorter penis, yeah fine... what? Say that again? The immature Davis is thinking... "Nah, check please. I'll just take the cancer, WTF." The mature Davis is thinking... "Sigh, alright, it's not like I can tell the kids down the road -- hey guys, Daddy had a potential cure, but now he's toast because he didn't want his penis to be shorter" Good lord. Real life can be stranger then fiction. Anyway, the wheel is in motion for my surgery, but what's the word on this issue you guys? Walsh kind of dismissed it as an urban myth in his book. My surgeon apparently has seen it in practice. Does it factor into the prostate size?(ie., Bigger prostate/bigger resection/shorter urethra afterwards) Curious.
Posts.Signature: 45 years old +1 family history PC PSA 2012 2.0 PSA 2015 3.5 PSA 2015 3.2 fPSA 2015 < 10% PHI 2015 45.0 Normal DRE 2015: 12 core Bx, two positive for PC: Left Base (38%) 3+3=6 and Right Medium (1%) 3+3=6 Gleason No perineal involvement. Prolaris Study: -1.5, low risk Da Vinci 9-18-15 Gleason upgraded to 4+3=7 Bilateral Dz, less then 5% prostate effected. Prostate 32.3 Grams Focal involvement at right apex margin, no extraprostatic involvement; lymph nodes and vesicles clear. PSA Oct. 2015: undetectable
Posts.Title: An Essay on Penis Shortening.

Posts.Content: MM, I just saw this and wanted you to know I was thinking about you. You are going to be fine, it's important that you hear that right now. Also, how do I say this, don't make the assumption that you are stuck with a G8. I don't have hard figures on this but, in many cases the Gleason will change after the prostate is removed. You could end up being downgraded.
Posts.Title: Sorry to be the newest member of the club

Posts.Content: PDV, I'm sorry man, I just read this. I'm glad you are feeling better already, that is a great sign that they have the right antibiotic on board as well. As frustrating as this is for you, keep your spirit up and remember it's just a nuisance problem, no worries.

Posts.Title: Sorry to be the newest member of the club

Posts.Content: John, sorry to hear about he first couple of days. On bright side it gets better from here. Just a means to an end. I was not one of the guys that got though it on tylenol only, lol. I don't know, I'm a big, tough guy in theory, but I was in the market pretty quicky for narcotics after my procedure. I had an unremarkable recovery, but I can't say it was a lot of fun. My second night was the worst really, I think the local wore off on the body wall incisions and I was at home in a normal bed, so getting up and down was rough. Hang in there. Your quality of life will return soon.

Posts.Content: MM, I just saw this and wanted you to know I was thinking about you. You are going to be fine, it's important that you hear that right now. Also, how do I say this, don't make the assumption that you are stuck with a G8. I don't have hard figures on this but, in many cases the Gleason will change after the prostate is removed. You could end up being downgraded.
Posts.Title: Sorry to be the newest member of the club

Posts.Content: MM, I just saw this and wanted you to know I was thinking about you. You are going to be fine, it's important that you hear that right now. You could end up being downgraded.
Posts.Title: Sorry to be the newest member of the club

Posts.Content: First of all, I want to thank you guys for your time and support. I did not realize until I started looking around, how many people come to the forum upset and without a real diagnosis yet. Chuck, that is a great point to ask for local pain control. Thankfully, this is not the Urologist that did my vasectomy! That dude was running behind schedule, and I'm fairly convinced lidocaine has to have a chance take effect first, lol. I will try and not think about it, and wait optimistically for actual results. I concluded last night, after reading every resource on the internet, that this approach was not helping a lot... I'm a vet by day. I tell people not to get freaked out by Dr. Google, and I've had a thousand cases turn into nothing when we work them up -- so you could argue that I should know better. Regardless, I will keep you all in my thoughts and hope you will do the same for me.
Posts.Title: I'm getting worked up, first biopsy next week.

Posts.Title: I'm getting worked up, first biopsy next week.

Posts.Content: John, sorry to hear about he first couple of days. On bright side it gets better from here. Just a means to an end. I was not one of the guys that got though it on tylenol only, lol. I don't know, I'm a big, tough guy in theory, but I was in the market pretty quicky for narcotics after my procedure. I had an unremarkable recovery, but I can't say it was a lot of fun. My second night was the worst really, I think the local wore off on the body wall incisions and I was at home in a normal bed, so getting up and down was rough. Hang in there. Your quality of life will return soon.
Posts.Signature: 45 years old +1 family history PC PSA 2012 2.0 PSA 2015 3.5 PSA 2015 3.2 fPSA 2015 < 10% PHI 2015 45.0 Normal DRE 2015: 12 core Bx, two positive for PC: Left Base (38%) 3+3=6 and Right Medium (1%) 3+3=6 Gleason No perineal involvement. Prolaris Study: -1.5, low risk Da Vinci 9-18-15 Gleason upgraded to 4+3=7 Bilateral Dz, less then 5% prostate effected. Prostate 32.3 Grams Focal involvement at right apex margin, no extraprostatic involvement; lymph nodes and vesicles clear. PSA Oct. 2015: undetectable
Posts.Title: First Week Journal - Days 1 to 3, post robotic radical prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Hello All. First post. I'm 45 with a +1 family history of PC. No symptoms, normal DRE. PSA two and a half years ago was 2.0 PSA last month was 3.5 on routine wellness screen. I was referred to a Urologist, and he offered the full range of options. I elected to take the new(er) PHI panel. The PHI came back as a 45 index reading, with a 32.7 % chance of cancer being present. The PSA within the panel was actually trending down (3.2) but free PSA was low at six percent, I believe. My urologist sounded very concerned and biopsies are scheduled. Let's just say the more I research the worse I feel about the situation. I can't find a lot of reference material for men in their 40's, which isn't helping me either. Many examples found just reference the aggressive forms of PC found in my age bracket. I keep trying to find a statistic to hold on to, but it just feels like a game of odds -- there will be three straws that day ...and don't pick the short one. I was hoping someone could give me some insight into how stressed one should be at this point, but I'm going into it with my eyes open. Does anybody have experience with the PHI? Thank you ahead of time.

Posts.Title: I'm getting worked up, first biopsy next week.

Posts.Content: Hey Guys, I don't have my Walsh book yet (on order), and I'm trying to wrap my head around the semantics on my recent path. report, just so I'm not looking through rose colored glasses. In addition to the two cores that showed 3+3, I had two cores which showed atypical small acinar proliferations. Each were small with one to three acinar aggregates. One had the absence of a basal cell layer by some type of cytokeratin cocktail and AMACR stains, and a path note saying "by size criterion the finding is not consistent with adenocarcinoma". I guess I was looking for some insight as to is this a precursor to adenocarcinoma and should I assume it as such? Meaning I really have four core positive samples? My understanding thus far is that high grade PIN's can go cancerous eventually, but unsure as to the ASAP lesions? One resource implied that ASAPs meant that the pathologist can't say it's a carcinoma, but has suspicion. I'm sure some of it is irrelevant, if I have 3+3, it doesn't change my treantment options -- but does it change prognosis, if more then one site of PC found? Thanks ahead of time.
Posts.Title: Need More Info on ASAP Lesions

Posts.Content: Well, I guess I can answer my own question now. Walsh does touch on this briefly in his book, but there is also a resource on the John Hopkins website. The short answer looks like yes. They are definite "maybe" for cellular changes associated with carcinoma -- probably not big enough yet to give the pathologist a true read. Additionally, you want to look harder for PC if you have these findings without a definitive positive on your biopsies. Now I get that it is a multifocal disease, that causes a field change in the whole gland. My impression is that traditionally three to seven small tumors are found on most prostatectomies and this doesn't change prognosis if still contained. I sent my slides on to Epstein for a second opinion BTW.

Prolaris Study: -1.5, low risk Da Vinci 9-18-15 Gleason upgraded to 4+3=7 Bilateral Dz, less then 5% prostate effected. Prostate 32.3 Grams Focal involvement at right apex margin, no extraprostatic involvement; lymph nodes and vesicles clear. PSA Oct. 2015: undetectable
